edge: The project was presented to Steven Spielberg at DreamWorks Pictures after going into turnaround from Bungalow 78 Productions, a division of TriStar Pictures.
Executive producer Michel Shane purchased the film rights for Paramount Pictures in 1990 and brought the project to DreamWorks.
By December 1997, Barry Kemp purchased the film rights from Michel Shane and brought the project to DreamWorks.
Producers Norman Lear and Bud Yorkin purchased the film rights to Frank Abagnale's autobiography in 1980.
Producer Hall Bartlett and business partner Michael J. Lasky hired Steven Kunes to write the screenplay for the project, but Bartlett died before finding a distributor.
By April 2000, Leonardo DiCaprio was in discussions to star in the project, with Gore Verbinski attached to direct.
In April 2000, David Fincher was attached to direct the project over the course of a few months, but dropped out in favor of Panic Room.
Spielberg signed on as producer for the project.
